meanings.definition: Accept something reluctantly but without protest.
meanings.sent1: She had to acquiesce to her brother's decision, even though she didn't want to.
meanings.sent2: The student had to acquiesce to the teacher's rules in the classroom.
meanings.sent3: He decided to acquiesce to the cat's demands for more treats.
meanings.sent4: The tree branches seemed to acquiesce to the strong wind, bending gracefully.
meanings.sent5: The old man's eyes seemed to acquiesce to the weight of years, tired but peaceful.

meanings.sent1: The team members had to acquiesce to the coach's strategy for the game.
meanings.sent2: The siblings had to acquiesce to their parents' decision to move to a new city.
meanings.sent3: The cat seemed to acquiesce to the idea of wearing a tiny hat for the party.
meanings.sent4: The waves of the ocean appeared to acquiesce to the pull of the moon, moving in harmony.
meanings.sent5: Her heart seemed to acquiesce to the melody of the music, feeling at peace.

meanings.definition: Submit or comply silently or without protest.
meanings.sent1: The workers had to acquiesce to the new company policy, even though they didn't agree with it.
meanings.sent2: The citizens had to acquiesce to the government's decision for the greater good.
meanings.sent3: The dog decided to acquiesce to the idea of wearing a silly costume for Halloween.
meanings.sent4: The flowers in the garden appeared to acquiesce to the gentle touch of the sunlight, blooming beautifully.
meanings.sent5: His mind seemed to acquiesce to the calming effect of the meditation, finding inner peace.
